examples.text: Anne was fond of Tim, though he often annoyed her.
Though she gave no sign, I was sure she had seen me.
His clothes, though old and worn, looked clean and of good quality.
Strange though it may sound, I was pleased it was over.

definitions.definition: used to add a fact or an opinion that makes the previous statement less strong or less important

examples.text: They're very different, though they did seem to get on well when they met.
He'll probably say no, though it's worth asking.

definitions.definition: in a way that suggests something

examples.text: He behaved as if nothing had happened.
It sounds as though you had a good time.
It's my birthday. As if you didn't know!
‘Don't say anything.’ ‘**As if I would!**’ *(= surely you do not expect me to)*
I like her, even though she can be annoying at times.

wordOrigin: Old English thēah, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German doch; superseded in Middle English by forms from Old Norse thó, thau.
